Text: Здесь вы узнаете все о том, как сделать хороший и плавный поворот. Последние кусочки головоломки для отличного полета!
Сев за очки, вы познакомитесь с режимом полета ACRO и пролетите через свои первые ворота.
Добро пожаловать в Liftoff! В этом уроке вы узнаете, что такое Liftoff и что вы можете ожидать от этой серии уроков. Вы также проверите свой контроллер, чтобы убедиться, что он готов к началу работы.
Первый полет в зоне прямой видимости даст вам представление о том, как контроллер влияет на работу дрона.
Испытание мастерства. Покажите, чему вы научились в этой серии уроков, и сразитесь с соперниками на нескольких трассах Liftoff.
Прохождение крутых поворотов - дело непростое и требует тонкого контроля и еще более тонких настроек.
Давайте закончим на более спокойной ноте. Мы расширим трассу и потренируем несколько широких, плавных поворотов.
Посмотрите, как это делается, а затем наступит ваша очередь.
Теперь попробуем повторить это упражнение, но уже в режиме ACRO.
Суть остается прежней: использовать одновременно рысканье и поворот, чтобы обогнуть угол.
Но поскольку в ACRO нет автостабилизации, нам придется вручную корректировать положение при выходе из поворота.
Вот дорожка в форме восьмерки. Это простая петля, которая позволяет отрабатывать повороты как влево, так и вправо.
Как всегда, смотрите и учитесь... После этого вы можете попробовать.
Поздравляю! Теперь вы узнали все самое важное о полетах FPV-дронов.
С этого момента все сводится к практике и совершенствованию своих навыков! Может пройти некоторое время, прежде чем все получится, но с каждой ошибкой вы будете становиться все лучше.
Мы подготовили для вас последний урок, в котором все сходится воедино: настоящая, полноценная гонка.
Если вы думаете, что у вас умеете делать всё что нужно... увидимся там!
Добро пожаловать на следующий урок полета!
До сих пор мы хорошо изучили только тангаж и газ, чтобы набирать высоту и лететь по прямой.
В этом уроке мы дополним ваш арсенал входов рысканьем и креном.
Они помогут вам при прохождении поворотов, будь то плавные виражи или стремительные зигзаги.
Давайте сделаем шаг назад и снова полетаем в режиме LEVEL. Так вы сможете сначала понять, как работают рысканье и крен.
После этого мы переключимся в режим ACRO.
Вот и все! Даже если это было очень сложно, постепенно это станет второй натурой.
Хотите ли вы повторить последнее упражнение этой сессии?
Не хотите ли вы попробовать еще раз, прежде чем мы продолжим?
Хорошо получилось! Похоже, вы справились с этой задачей.
Это было плавное движение. Готовы попробовать?
Сначала мы пройдемся против часовой стрелки. По сути, это просто один огромный круг.
Мы будем постоянно и плавно регулировать рысканье и крен.
Хорошо, теперь мы покрутимся вокруг этого конуса, а затем повторим тот же большой круг в противоположном направлении.
Готовы попробовать? Имейте в виду: это, пожалуй, самое сложное упражнение в серии. Не будьте слишком строги к себе, если потребуется несколько попыток.
Давайте сначала выполним еще один демонстрационный запуск.
Обратите особое внимание на ввод угла наклона.
Вместо того чтобы толкать его вперед, как в режиме LEVEL, мы должны немного опустить его вниз, чтобы избежать столкновения дрона с землей.
Как обычно, мы начинаем с легкого подталкивания к pitch, чтобы начать движение вперед.
Cнова, как и раньше, мы направляем рысканье и крен в одном направлении для плавного поворота.
Но... выходя из поворота, мы отпускаем рысканье, одновременно вручную выравнивая дрон по крену.
Постарайтесь проехать по трассе несколько раз, прежде чем мы продолжим.
Чтобы правильно завершить поворот, вам придется одновременно использовать рысканье и крен.
Перемещайте стики в одном направлении с примерно одинаковой силой.
Конечно, вам также понадобится немного питча, чтобы сохранить достаточный импульс для завершения поворота.
При выходе из поворота просто отпустите рысканье и крен.
В режиме LEVEL дрон снова автоматически стабилизируется.
Ладно... Так ничего и не вышло...
Как будто дрон катается по льду. Он скользит прямо мимо поворота!
Yaw alone isn't going to cut it. We'll also need to involve roll to make the turn.
Let's see if we can fly around that golf flag using just yaw.
Remember how yaw turns the drone in its horizontal plane? Like this...
Well, there you have it... You've learned everything there is to learn!
There's much to do in Liftoff. Keep practicing in single player, or give multiplayer a go and see how you stack up against pilots across the world!
Or you could try customizing drones in the Workbench or designing your own tracks and races in the Track Builder.
Whatever you like, remember to have fun and keep flying!
That's insane! You just came out on top in your first two races!
You're clearly a natural at this!
Let's pit you against some of the Liftoff regulars in a friendly race.
It's the same track, but for three laps. First across the finish line wins!
You obviously have what it takes, but to win your very first race... that's something else entirely.
So, how about it? Think you're ready for a small race?
Welcome to the final chapter of this tutorial series!
Over the previous sessions, you've learned to fully control a drone in ACRO mode.
However, those were all isolated cases, practicing a very specific type of input.
This time, you won't be learning anything new anymore, but you'll have a go at a few real Liftoff race tracks!
These will put your skills to the test, and measure how far you've come as a pilot over the course of this training.
We've also invited some friends over for a bit of friendly competition.
Once you've made yourself familiar with a track, we'll have a little race to see how you hold up.
Alright. Let's go over the first track here.
This one is pretty level and has wide turns. Nothing too technical. Ideal for a warm-up.
Go ahead and explore before we bring in the competition.
Ok, here we go! Show 'm what you got, pilot!
You just aced your second race! You might just go far in the world of FPV.
Excellent! Ready for the final race?
Nice job! Let's have a look at another real Liftoff track.
This one's a lot more technical than the last one. Tighter corners and spaces, different obstacles, and a few gates placed higher up.
It's the ultimate test for everything you've learned in these sessions!
Take all the time you need to explore this one.
Once you finish a lap, we'll bring in the competition.
Here's a new track. The gates are slightly smaller, but more importantly: there's height differences.
This way you can practice throttle and pitch some more.
The speed at which you approach gates now becomes important as well.
Now, let's switch over to ACRO mode.
ACRO is short for 'acrobatic' and is the flight mode most commonly used for racing or freestyle.
Unlike LEVEL mode, it doesn't limit the orientation of your drone in sharp corners or dives, or during loops and tricks.
All that freedom comes at a cost. Your drone won't level itself automatically anymore!
This makes ACRO mode a bit harder to master, but you'll get the hang of it soon enough.
But first things first... Let's see how it works.
This was a big first step in flying ACRO-mode.
Providing throttle and pitch is a difficult balancing act that takes some practice.
Don't hestitate to practice this more in other environments.
For the final challenge, let's kick things up a notch...
This first track is pretty clear-cut: fly through these gates in a straight line.
You should get by with just throttle and pitch. We'll leave yaw and roll alone for now.
Remember, we're still in LEVEL mode. Just like before, the drone levels when no input is given.
Have a look at how it's done first. After that, it's your turn!
Going from LEVEL to ACRO mode is a huge step.
Generally, you don't want to spend too much time in LEVEL mode. It will teach you habits that are hard to break out of once you start flying in ACRO.
In the next lesson, we'll reintroduce yaw and roll to complete your basic flight training.
In this tutorial we'll start flying in first-person view, or FPV for short.
First, we'll focus on flying in a straight line. We'll still keep the drone in LEVEL mode for that.
After that, we're switching over to ACRO mode, and you'll have to combine flying forward with altitude control.
Let's take a look at the track...
Now provide some pitch by pushing your right stick slightly up.
Stop once it starts going forward.
Wonderful! You'll find that altitude control is crucial to FPV flying.
Just like before, you will have to arm your drone before you can take off.
Let's move on to the next step...
Now provide some pitch the other way by pushing your right stick slightly down. This will slow the drone down.
Now provide some pitch. Bring the right stick up slightly and keep it there.
If you get to close to the ground, add a little throttle as well.
That should guide you through the gates pretty smoothly.
As you can tell, ACRO requires more finesse in moving your sticks.
Even small inputs have an immediate effect and each mistake needs to be corrected.
Ready to give it a try?
Remember to only use pitch and throttle. The other inputs will just steer you off track.
In fact, we'll even bring pitch down again to brake.
There's no leveling either... Once the drone has slowed down enough, we have to manually level it out.
Same procedure as before. Push pitch up to tilt and move forward.
However, we're no longer limited in orientation! Once when we reach the tilt we need, we have to stop providing pitch.
Once again, we'll try and not touch yaw and roll. They're not necessary for flying dead ahead.
With ACRO mode being more sensitive, even a small bit of input can push you off course.
No need to sugarcoat it: this is a pretty difficult exercise already.
Give yourself plenty of tries to master the controls on this small track.
Now we need to get back down again. Cut the throttle slightly to lose altitude.
As we approach the elevated gate, we need to slow down by pitching back.
Also, we need to gain altitude. We'll give the throttle stick a brief push to have the drone jump through the gate.
There you have it. Should be easy enough, right?
Now you give it a go!
Pitch works both ways. If you push pitch down, you can reduce forward momentum by tilting the drone backwards a little.
Of course... keep that up too long and your drone will start going backwards.
A drone doesn't have a "go button". Instead, you fly forward by tilting the drone.
We'll provide a little pitch with the right stick. This will tilt the drone forward.
But... there's a catch! When the drone tilts forward, it loses a bit of upward force.
That means we might have to raise throttle a bit to compensate for that.
Alright, that's it for now. You're good to go!
See you in the next tutorial!
If you notice that your input is jittery, try increasing the deadband for the axes in question.
You might need this level of accuracy for future exercises.
In this tutorial series, we'll teach you how to get your drone off the ground and into the air.
First off, we'll have a look at your radio. You won't be going anywhere if that doesn't work properly.
Next up, you'll be flying line-of-sight, just to get a first feel for how a drone reacts to your inputs.
Once you got that down, we'll be introducing throttle control and flying in a straight line.
After that, you can practice cornering on a simple track.
And finally... you'll be participating in your very first drone race!
Mind you, flying a race drone is not a skill most people can pick up just like that.
But no worries! With a little time and perseverance, it will soon become second nature!
Alright! Before taking off, let's make sure your gear is in working order.
Here's another crucial piece of equipment. Radio, RC, remote, controller,... Call it what you like.
The point is: this is what lets you give input to your drone.
So before continuing, let's make sure all inputs are set up correctly.
Nice! Seems like all input axes are being detected.
Do all stick movements match what you'd expect? Or is something not right?
Hmm... Liftoff isn't picking up any input. Maybe it needs some help interpreting your controller's input first.
Hmm... Liftoff couldn't pick up all the required axes. Maybe it needs some help interpreting your controller's input first.
Move your controller's sticks around. The controller on the table should respond.
This is the star of the show. A fully assembled drone setup. Ready for Liftoff!
A drone consists of many components. There's your frame, your motors, propellers, battery... Each of these comes in a wide range of technical specifications.
Liftoff combines all that into realistic and detailed flight behavior for your exact drone.
That way, every hour spent in Liftoff translates directly to real-life piloting skills!
Drones in Liftoff feature a custom-built flight controller that mimics features found in the real world.
You can fine-tune how your drone responds, from smooth freestyle flying to quick cornering for races.
The flight controller also sports different flight modes, such as LEVEL or ACRO, as well as various useful functions such as turtle mode and launch control.
Your goggles pick up the drone's wireless video feed. They allow you to look through the camera mounted on the front of the drone.
It's like you're looking directly through the drone's eyes. That's why it's called First Person View flying, or FPV!
Hmm... The system couldn't detect any controller. Is it plugged in?
We can't complete this step if there's no controller detected.
On this table is everything you need to get started: a radio or controller, a set of FPV goggles, a drone setup, some spare parts...
Let's see what we have here, shall we?
Good job! That concludes this tutorial. Next up... we're gonna be flying FPV!
Before we dive into FPV flying, let's start by flying line-of-sight for a while.
It's just as tricky, but it does give you a good look at how a drone reacts to your inputs.
Also, we'll set the drone in LEVEL-mode for now. It will automatically level when you let go of the sticks.
This way, you can get a feel for the inputs before we move on to something more advanced.
Okay, sit back for a minute. We'll show you how it's done first and then you can take over.
Good. Now that you know how your inputs affect the drone, let's put that to the test.
Here's a small track with three colored circles.
Fly the drone through each to complete the challenge.
Your drone is currently in disarmed. You won't be able to provide input to the motors.
Perform your arming action to arm it.
Your drone is currently disarmed. You won't be able to provide input to the motors.
Move throttle all the way down to arm it.
Now, let's focus on the right stick of your controller: pitch and roll.
Go ahead and just experiment with these axes a bit. Get a feel for them without worrying too much about where you're going.
Of course, you'll want to stay in the air. Don't forget to manage your throttle!
Awesome! You're getting the hang of it. Let's give you some targets to aim for.
Nice. Now that we're armed, let's try working with the left stick first: throttle and yaw.
First, use throttle to gain a little altitude. Try to keep that altitude steady for a few seconds.
Before we dive into FPV flying, let's start by flying line-of-sight for a while.
Alright, try to keep your altitude steady for a few seconds.
Now try and make a full turn, using yaw.
Like before, you'll have to arm the drone before it can take off.
There you go! Now, fly the drone into each circle to complete the challenge.
As a safety measure, a drone always starts in the disarmed state. It won't react to any input.
To arm your drone, you will have to perform an action, depending what you've set up in your input configuration.
For the purposes of this tutorial, this drone here will arm when throttle is brought all the way down.
Alright, that's the four axes on the controller. Now you give it a try!
Moving on to the right stick...
The vertical axis on the right stick controls pitch. Pitch tilts the drone forward, so that it can gain speed.
Finally, the horizontal axis on the right stick controls roll. Roll is the sideways rotation of the drone.
There we go. Now that the drone is armed, it will react to input. Let's get it off the ground.
Throttle is mapped to the vertical axis on the left stick. Pushing throttle up makes the drone take off.
The horizontal axis on that same left stick is mapped to yaw.
Yaw makes the drone turn on its horizontal plane.
Mind that you don't just magically maintain altitude.
With every maneuver, you simultaneously also need to manage your throttle.
Your inputs were detected successfully! If the movements of the virtual controller matched to yours, then you can continue. Or, you can choose to go to the controller calibration menu.
No controller was detected by the system. Please connect a compatible controller and try again.
No inputs were detected. Would you like to try and calibrate your controller?
Some inputs were detected, but not all of them. Would you like to try and calibrate your controller?
Would you like to try this exercise again before continuing?

EARLY ACCESS! Thanks for participating in our Early Access program. This version of Liftoff is a work in progress and may not represent the final product. With your help we can build something truly special. Bugs, feedback, suggestions? Let us know on the Steam forums or through the contact form on the Liftoff website. Like the game? Post a nice review on Steam. The team at LuGus Studios really appreciates it.

Along with your feedback, we will automatically collect some generic information such as your operating system, resolution, and your save file to help us solve any problems you describe.

A core piece of equipment for flying an FPV drone is your remote or controller. It's essential that it is working correctly to get a smooth Liftoff experience.

Click the button below to make sure your controller is detected and working properly.

In order to track your player progression, receive rewards and compete in the Liftoff Pro League, you will need a Liftoff Pro account.

A Liftoff Pro account is completely optional, but we recommend registering to get the full Liftoff experience.

Click the button below to register.

That's it! You're ready to take to the skies.

Ready! Set! LIFTOFF!
Liftoff simulates a wide range of drone systems. Select a preset below that best matches your FPV experience.
You can further fine-tune your settings and preferences by clicking the button below.
This preset enables all additional simulation systems to give you the most realistic FPV experience.
This preset allows you to focus on the essentials of flying an FPV drone. Additional simulations are disabled.
You can still change these options later in the main menu or in the pause menu.
If you ever want to calibrate a new controller, recalibrate your current one, or change some keybindings, then look for this panel in the main menu.

To quickly navigate through menus or use game functions during flight, you can assign actions to buttons on your keyboard and controller.

Click below to have a look at what you can do in Liftoff.

Hello, and welcome to Liftoff!

In just a few steps, we'll get you ready to rip through the skies! But first, pick a language that you would to use in Liftoff.
Note: English is the recommended language for online, social and support features.

Some controllers need calibration to work properly. To start calibration, center all joysticks and click "Calibrate".
Click Calibrate if the drone does not react as expected. Alternatively, fine-tune the current calibration by clicking on Fine-tune.
Rotate all joysticks in big circles. Make sure you reach all the edges. When finished, click the button again.
Center all sticks to go to next step

You have finished calibrating the joysticks.

Think something went wrong? You can calibrate again by centering the sticks and clicking "Retry Calibrate".

Hi Linux user!
If you are about to calibrate an RC remote, please be aware of the pre-calibration steps that are required before calibrating your remote in Liftoff. You can find a detailed guide by clicking on the link below.

You can ignore this message if you want to calibrate a game controller.

Maybe the axis didn't calibrate properly?

Try using the current position as the center, increasing the dead zone or clicking cancel and restarting the calibration proces.

1. Make sure the controller is switched on and connected to your computer before starting the game. 2. Make sure you have the right cable and/or dongle for your specific remote. 3. Consult the manual of your remote to see how you should connect your remote to the computer. 4. Make sure your system is receiving input from your remote. 5. Steam could be interfering with your controller recognition. Go to Steam and under Steam > Settings > Controller > General Controller Settings, make sure Generic Gamepad Configuration Support is turned off. Still couldn't connect? Please contact the manufacturer of your hardware device for support on how to connect the controller to a computer. Liftoff is not responsible for problems with your hardware setup but is happy to help when possible.
Select the desired axis from the grid below .
Select which channel to assign to an axis.

Test your controller input and see if the drone responds as expected.

You can save your calibration or, if something went wrong, you can calibrate again.
There are unsaved changes. Do you want to discard the changes and go back?
E.g. XBox One controller for Windows
If a controller isn't responding after selecting or creating a preset, you can select a different controller number here.
Checking input. Please move the stick as shown.
Couldn't detect the axis you moved. If this problem persists, try calibrating the controller first.
Succesfully set the axis. Try moving and check if the drone model behaves correctly.
Succesfully set the axis. Try moving and check if the drone model behaves correctly. If your input appears to be inverted, try clicking "Invert" below.
We will now bind the Pitch axis. When you're ready, click "Set Pitch". What is Pitch? Pitch allows you to tilt the drone forwards and backwards. This is used to move forward or to brake.

We will now bind the Pitch axis. Move your stick in the direction shown in the image and click below on the channel that receives input. What is Pitch? Pitch allows you to tilt the drone forwards and backwards. This is used to move forward or to brake.
We will now bind the Roll axis. When you're ready, click "Set Roll". What is Roll? Roll allows you to... roll. Use this together with Yaw to bank in corners.

We will now bind the Roll axis. Move your stick in the direction shown in the image and click below on the channel that receives input. What is Roll? Roll allows you to... roll. Use this together with Yaw to bank in corners.
We will now bind the Throttle axis. When you're ready, click "Set Throttle". What is Throttle? Throttle adjusts the speed at which your propellers rotate. You can use this to go higher or faster.

We will now bind the Throttle axis. Move your stick in the direction shown in the image and click below on the channel that receives input. What is Throttle? Throttle adjusts the speed at which your propellers rotate. You can use this to go higher or faster.
We will now bind the Yaw axis. When you're ready, click "Set Yaw". What is Yaw? Yaw rotates the drone around its center, allowing you to face left or right.

We will now bind the Yaw axis. Move your stick in the direction shown in the image and click below on the channel that receives input. What is Yaw? Yaw rotates the drone around its center, allowing you to face left or right.
Press @@@KEY_RESET to quickly reset your quad to its start position.
You can share Tracks and Races you created via the Steam Workshop.
In the Main Menu's Options section you can configure various game options.
In the Option Menu's Controls section you can select and create new Controller Presets and assign keyboard and controller buttons.
When flying your quad, you can edit various Flight Controller Settings in the Pause Menu.
Press any button to quickly skip the goggle animation at the start of your flight or automatically skip it by setting the option in the Options menu.
Double tap @@@KEY_JUMP in the Track editor to activate floaty mode.
Press the radio button in the top right corner of any menu to skip a song.
You can remap all your buttons in the Button Setup window.
Press @@@KEY_FREEFLIGHTTOGGLE in Free Flight to switch between flying and placing your quad.
Press @@@KEY_LOSTOGGLE to switch between line of sight and the other drone perspectives.
Press @@@KEY_FLIGHTMODETOGGLE to cycle between Acro, 3D and Level flight mode.
Don't forget to give your custom drone a name and description in the Workbench
Multiplayer: Click on the player icon to spectate that pilot.
Want to up your freeflight skills? Try flying in 3D mode.
Having trouble flying in 3D mode? Try levelling your camera.
Like Liftoff? Leave us a nice review on Steam.
Hit something? Press @@@KEY_REWIND to rewind time.
Press @@@KEY_CAMERAANGLEUP and @@@KEY_CAMERAANGLEDOWN to change your camera angle in-game.
Show your freestyle skills in the Freestyle game mode!
Want to join the online fun? Don't forget to create a Liftoff Pro account!
Make sure to check the game options to tweak your game experience.
Press @@@KEY_NOISETOGGLE to toggle FPV camera noise.
Want to practice battery management? Activate battery simulation in the game options.
Pushing your lipo to its limits can be dangerous, be careful not to burn it.
Purist mode is available in Multiplayer for those seeking pure realism.
Create up to a million unique drone setups in the Workbench.
Adding an action cam to your setup will increase the total weight of your drone.
A setup with an action cam will give you a bonus in Freestyle mode.
Activate a fish eye effect by pressing @@@KEY_FISHEYE.
Hitting different objects and materials in-game will result in different crash and damage results.
Press @@@KEY_VIEWPOINTTOGGLE to cycle between first and third person views.
Practice your skills in Free Flight Mode, with or without a Track.
Best your own record time in Race Mode.
In the Workbench you can edit your drone's layout and components for a different flying experience.
In the Track Builder you can create new Tracks for each of Liftoff's environments.
In the Race Editor you can define Races for Tracks you created.

The Liftoff Pro League is an initiative to help turn the top Liftoff players into professional Liftoff pilots. For those keen on making a name in the drone racing world, racing in Liftoff is as much a career choice as flying a real drone. The Liftoff Pro League will help you become a professional player by offering an e-sports service completely integrated into Liftoff.

No rules, no stress! Hone your piloting skills, get a feel for the environment or practice on a track of your choice.
Dives, flips, rolls and tumbles. Push your quad to the limit and grab as many points as you can by pulling off daring tricks and death-defying stunts.
Improve your lap times and stay in "the zone" in this infinite race!
Start flying right where you left last time and save time going through options and menu's.
Not a fan of casually scrolling through the levels and your drones? Quickly set your desired level and get flying!
Start a randomly selected race session and prove you can handle every situation thrown at you!
Show everyone what you got! Pick a race and shatter the record time.

Tired of roaming around aimlessly? Create your own track!

Place flags, gates and other objects to create exciting race challenges.
Learn the basics of drone piloting in a series of tutorials and complementary tracks on which to practice.
Learn the basics of drone piloting in a series of video tutorials and complementary tracks on which to practice.
Set up everything you need to start flying in this step-by-step process.

Aether was designed by Sander Nysten with the objective of creating an innovative, aesthetically pleasing and compact drone.
The Armattan Chameleon is a lovingly calculated, dedicated freestyle frame developed and produced by Armattan Quads.
Designed around the best principals that brought the Japalura and the Rooster to the front of their fields, this frame gives you the best protection and quality.
The Armattan Mongoose is one of Armattan's Lite series of frames, and is built to be inexpensive, strong, and light.
The Armattan Rooster takes the Chameleon concept to a completely new level. Stronger materials, improved design and better provisions coupled with the ability to swap arms with ease.
The Borrum is an all-purpose X-frame.
Designed by the one and only Botgrinder aka Doug Crasher, the BOT5 is made to take ruthless abuse and silly crashes and laugh it off.
Sleek and aerodynamic, the DJI FPV aircraft delivers powerful propulsion, battery life and wind resistance, making this system as capable as it is visually stunning.

The Addiction is a middle-weight frame which offers incredible strength. Continuously improving the design has led to the point where this frame is one of the strongest out there while still being sub 100 grams.
Due to its unique milled arm channels on the main and bottom plates, the frame is very strong and very light! Made available worldwide at your favorite FPV stores!
T​op mount freestyle frame that is fast, compact, agile and is made from the highest quality carbon in the market today!
The combination of aircraft grade aluminum and carbon fiber not only makes this frame super fancy but also really strong!
The combination of aircraft grade aluminum and carbon fiber not only makes this frame super fancy but also really strong! Longer arms allow for 6 inch prop.
This frame is based around two vertical 1mm carbon fiber plates with 3d-printed parts holding them together. All necessary components (including FPV) fit in between.
Flite Test's line of frames that is laminated delrin to give an awesome look.

hy phy / noun
1. extremely rowdy, excited, or energetic. "the whole group is gonna get super hyphy for Adam's frame"
Khole (noun) - An intense out of body experience where one is sometimes connected with spirits. Only a higher state of consciousness could have brought this frame to realization.

The Luma 5 is the ultimate all-round Freestyle quad. Its squished X symmetrical geometry ensures balanced control on all axes, and its ideal flight weight makes it perfect for maneuvering around proximity subjects.

A new French, squished 215mm frame, designed with two bottom plates and 6mm thick arms. Every part is cut from very dense "silky" carbon, made in Europe. The AK is a high quality, super sturdy frame, made by the passionate pilots of Team Mistral.
Open source 3D printable frame by Freezillion.
The CL1, was designed in collaboration with the Rotor Riot community. They took pilots’ input and implemented what they wanted into this design.
Let's Fly RC wanted one thing out of his new frame more than anything else, and that's for it to survive any and all damage. Just like a tank.
Skycopter offers an innovative approach to industrial inspections and first response emergency situations.
True to its name, this eye-catching, glowing frame designed by Sander Nysten is best suited for recreational flight due to its fixed camera.
The unique design of the Talon's arms creates minimum air turbulence and superior handling performance at high speeds.
Tommy Tibajia dreamed of a truly balanced quad with most of the weight as close to the CG as possible. His dream has come true.
Developed for several months in our laboratories and in our test centers, the Vega HSX-R is the culmination of our know-how.
A cool looking frame designed by 2016 world-cup champion VINCBEE
Following the incredible success of the Vortex 285 and Vortex 250 Pro, the Vortex 150 Mini raises the bar and at the same time shrinks the size.
The big brother of the popular Vortex 150, tuned for the track.
The Vortex 230 Mojo is a crossover race/freestyle quad, excellent on the track, and a heaps of fun for freestyling.
The first Vortex by ImmersionRC is a unique foldable quad designed for racing. A tried and tested frame, loved by many.
The second in a series of Vortex drones, the first Racebred ARF quad. Smaller than its bigger brother, it's built for speed and designed to take some serious abuse.
This variation on the Vortex 250 Pro features longer arms that allow for bigger propellers. Designed and approved by FPV legend Metall Danny.
Le Drib designed his signature frame, the Skyeliner, to be simple in construction, aesthetic in design, and durable in crashing.
The MaiOnHigh Edition of our Atom Bomb Baby 2306 motors designed in the US by Miss Creature
The coolest motor on the block.
The design of the Hypetrain Blaster resembles a Radiation Hazard symbol, evoking memories of Rotor Riot’s radioactive adventures in Chernobyl.
The beautiful design and attention to detail of the Hypetrain Acro motor sets it apart from the competition.
The design of the Hypetrain Blaster resembles a Radiation Hazard symbol, evoking memories of Rotor Riot’s radioactive adventures in Chernobyl.
Designed from the ground up with constant input from Kevin "Stingersswarm" Dougherty, the attention to detail of the Hypetrain Stingersswarm Motor sets it apart from the competition.
The beautiful design and attention to detail of the Hypetrain Vanover motor sets it apart from the competition.
The beautiful design and attention to detail of the Hypetrain Freestyle motor sets it apart from the competition.
Designed from the ground up with constant input from Drew "Drib" Camden, the attention to detail of the Hypetrain Le Drib Motor sets it apart from the competition.

Designed from the ground up with constant input from Tommy "Ummagawd" Tibajia, the attention to detail of the Hypetrain Ummagawd Motor sets it apart from the competition.
The beautiful design and attention to detail of the Hypetrain Cricket motor sets it apart from the competition.
The beautiful design and attention to detail of the Hypetrain Freestyle V2 motor sets it apart from the competition.
The Hypetrain Grinders were designed by Botgrinder to withstand the abuse he puts his quads through. They are grinders!
A lightweight motor with a Kv of 2450.
This feisty motor packs quite a punch.
Custom motor for the Vortex 150 Mini.
It is as beautiful as it is powerful
An efficient and powerful 5x5 triblade propeller.
Small tri-blade props that pack a punch.
